pros:
Working at Comic Relief has been a breath of fresh air. Coming from a corporate background, I was looking for a job that gave me purpose and new lease of energy into my career.

I've definitely found that here. Not only is this a charity that does amazing things, but it's leading the way in some very innovative grant-making which feels awesome. The company has also gone through a restructure and there is such a sense of energy and drive here at the moment.

Having said that, I have also been enjoying some work/life balance! We all work hard and put in the hours when they're needed, but recognise that we are all more than just worker bees. So leaving on time is encouraged! Not only that, there is flexibility to work from home, or job share which is so refreshing.

The team is great - we have an LGBT+ community, netball and softball teams, book club - there is plenty of ways to get to know the wider team. 

If you're thinking of making the switch to charity work - do! :)
cons: Some processes are still sort of mid-change which can make things a little confusing - we'll get there though!

review_title: Appalling - the trustees have a lot to answer for
pros: It is an important cause
cons:
2 huge restructures in the space of just 3 years have left this organisation in pieces. An incredible amount of money has been wasted making hundreds of extremely experienced staff redundant, only to promote more junior, inexperienced staff into their vacant roles - leading to organisational chaos. 

Reliance on expensive consultants - wasting the talent that already exists within the organisation

Childish in-fighting between senior management

Culture of favouritism from the top down leads to toxic environment

pros: Social activities and wonderful beneficiaries.  Great to work somewhere that does raise a lot of money for good causes.
cons:
Lots of talk of change yet it comes so slowly that it becomes an incredibly frustrating place to work especially if you are a driven, dynamic individual. The result being that those who are worth their salt ultimately land up leaving resulting in high staff turnover. 

The company are massively understaffed which leads to others taking on more than they signed up for with little to no remuneration or support.  
They seem to have developed this new policy to only promote internally which whilst it is cited as “great for development” more often leads to inexperienced, immature people in senior positions only adding to the flux of the organisation. 

Those who do stay suffer often suffer burn out / anxiety as a result of the culture. Lots of talk about work / life balance and mental health support but time and time again when flagged to management, nothing concrete is done apart from a sympathetic look and a pat on the shoulder. 

Endless meeting culture which is incredibly unproductive. Means you spend most of your time discussing / debating what you are going to do, rather than actually doing it. 

No genuine career development or objective setting - it’s a box ticking exercise. The People Team / HR are not person-centred in their approach nor demeanour. So sense they are there to support or encourage in any way. 

My experience at Comic Relief has been disappointing. Promised a dynamic organisation on my job role but sadly this company is anything but...(and yes, I am looking to leave the company).

review_title: There is a reason their rating is so low
pros: Work life balance is good, office is in a decent location, ridiculously relaxed management
cons:
Unless you fit their mould and are willing to intertwine your personal life with your professional, then you are ignored, even if you are more informed on a subject.  

Nothing can ever be a simple.  There are obviously aspects of any project that have to be analysed and assessed but getting anything over the line goes at a glacial pace until the deadline is moments away  when it suddenly becomes a priority. 

Management shy away from responsibility.  There is a real blame culture, finger pointing is rife.

If you aren't friends with the management, prepare to be left out of conversations and expect to find out everything on your own, and then be blamed for being slow / uninformed

Nepotism is popular.  Again, if you are mates with the management you can expect promotions regardless of your experience or ability.  

The reason the campaign feels so hectic here is because there is no emphasis to get work done in a timely manner.  Annual projects seem to be forgotten about until they are days away and then you have to drag them over the line.   

Certain teams claim to be so understaffed that they can't even reply to emails or attend meetings.  Somehow this is then blamed on everyone apart from the management team.  

Communication is generally poor here.  Again this comes back to if you aren't mates with the management you get told nothing.  If you do work here I would recommend documenting bad communication practices as you will be scapegoated.  

I would not recommend working here unless you want to kill all your professional ambition.
